Om die strak te verwerken, moeten we de – per definitie beperkte – capaciteit in de warehouses slim benutten. Crunch jij hoe? De grootste uitdaging Bol.com groeit razendsnel. Dat is positief, maar brengt ook uitdagende vraagstukken met zich mee. Uit welk magazijn kunnen we een bestelling het best verzenden? Hoe zorgen we ervoor dat klanten hun bestellingen vaker in één verpakking ontvangen? Welk assortiment leggen we waar neer? We hebben een steeds complexere logistieke operatie en moeten toch zo goedkoop mogelijk blijven en altijd de volgende dag kunnen leveren; capacity management. Elk project is anders en vergt een unieke aanpak. Dat is meteen een van jouw uitdagingen: Met jouw unieke data-skills ontwikkel en verbeter je deze processen, IT services en/of (data science) modellen bestaande uit een brede variëteit van variabelen. This project aims at developing a novel reconstruction framework, which will turn MRI-based electrical properties measurements into a new biomarker for early-stage radiotherapy treatments assessment, and at testing it in clinical settings. In particular, you will develop a novel reconstruction framework integrating physics-based reconstruction methods and deep-learning solutions. To create the data used to train and validate such framework, you will perform electromagnetic simulations and MRI measurements on phantoms and in-vivo. You will benchmark in-vivo electrical properties reconstructions against metabolic sodium-MRI using a unique high-field metabolic scanner present at the radiotherapy department. Ultimately, to demonstrate the clinical applicability of tissue electrical properties imaging for diagnosis and early-stage assessment of radiotherapy treatments, you will perform the first study in brain tumor patients facilitated by the radiology and radiotherapy departments. The success of this project will open a window into personalized radiotherapy treatments and improve their cost/efficiency. The lack of ionizing radiation and the excellent soft tissue contrast make Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) the key imaging method in radiation oncology to diagnose cancer and monitor the efficacy of radiotherapy treatments. Currently, the assessment of radiotherapy treatments relies on surrogate indicators derived from MRI images, which show changes only months after treatment. To monitor the efficacy of radiotherapy treatments at earlier stages, new quantitative MRI biomarkers are needed. Radiotherapy alters tissue viability at early-stages of treatment, leading to abnormal electrolyte concentrations, where sodium is the most important electrolyte determining the electromagnetic properties of tissues. Tissue electromagnetic properties would therefore represent an original biomarker to assess tissue viability allowing early-stage treatment assessment. Tissue electrical properties images can in principle be reconstructed from clinical MRI measurements. Details Duration  Minimum of 4 months   Location  Depending on government’s Covid regulations at home or at the Royal HaskoningDHV office in Amersfoort or Nijmegen.    Assignment Improve our workflow to calculate surface reflectance (Albedo) from a Sentinel2 composite of images taken in a summer period, and validate it using the heat calculation (UCAM) method and in situ measurements. Background  Urban Heat Island effect Climate change is making our planet warmer and more extreme. Long periods of heat and drought are more common than they used to be in the past. As more and more people are moving into cities, urban areas are expanding. Buildings and roads replace vegetated areas[1]. Open, permeable soil is covered by impermeable and dry surfaces. As there is no water to evaporate, the suns energy is trapped between buildings, and absorbed by bricks and cement. This causes urban areas to heat up to 1-3 °C more than their neighbouring rural areas. This is called the Urban Heat Island (UHI) effect. The higher temperatures increase the risk of heat stress, resulting in health risks.  The Heat Monitor We, as heat risk advisors within Royal HaskoningDHV, support municipalities in their quest to keep our cities and villages healthy and liveable in the future by identifying the areas that are prone to heat risk and advise on mitigating measures. In the middle of our approach to identify and tackle areas of heat stress is the Heat monitor. This is a 3d digital twin supporting policy makers in tackling heat-stress using solid, validable data in an easy to interpret visualisation. It shows priorities for municipality policy makers where to start implementing improvement measures.  At the core of the Heat Monitor is the UCAM ((Urban Climate Assessment & Management) method. This method is developed by our lead heat stress consultant Ronald Groen together with Wageningen University, Witteveen+Bos and the KNMI.  Albedo An important factor that determines the UHI effect is the surface reflectance, i.e. albedo. A low albedo means less solar radiation is reflected away from the surface, leaving more energy to be absorbed by the buildings and streets. An accurate calculation of albedo is therefore important to correctly advise on the locations where inhabitants are at risk of heat stress.
